It was all anyone could ever have wanted; it was all she thought she could ever want, and yet there was emptiness. She could scream for hours, but the house was so big no one would hear. It was enough to drive one mad. Was it the madness that drove her out a window, or the abscence of love?

Change. It something we all do as a race. It's happened for as long as the earth has exsisted. We adapt to survive, so that the strongest among can carry on with the tradition. Some people I guess tend to forget that it happened, and that it's still happening. They're comfortable in the bubble they've created for themselves. Or maybe they haven't forgotten, maybe they're just afraid if they stepped outside, that natural selection would kick their ass. It probably would.

The window was old. Blurry after centuries, the top pane was brittle. Thin, as the glass had run, smearing the view little by little. I often wonder if it ran because it cried, living its life slowly but surely ignored. Never seen, but seen through. What would it  be like to be an invisible object? Never loved for what you are, but for what others see through you. ...Bittersweet.
